questions.text: A concerned mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day-old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below.  Microscopic examination of this lesion revealed neutrophils. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over the arms of a newborn, with the presence of neutrophils on microscopic examination is suggestive of transient pustular melanosis.

Transient pustular melanosis is a benign condition seen more commonly among African-American neonates than Caucasian neonates. They present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles. The pustular phase lasts for 2-3 days and no therapy is required. However, the subsequent hyperpigmented macules may last for up to 3 months.

Samples from the lesion can be cultured and smears can be prepared. They contain neutrophils and will not contain bacteria or aggregates of eosinophils. This distinguishes these lesions from those of pyoderma and erythema toxicum respectively. More dangerous lesions like the vesicular eruptions of herpes simplex and staphylococcal skin infections need to be ruled out by appropriate testing. 

Other options:

Option B - Mongolian spots are slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

Option C - Erythema toxicum is another transient condition characterized by small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.

Option D - Cutis marmorata is a transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of the skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text:
Which of the following are valid indications for transfusion FFP in a newborn?
  1. Enhancement of wound healing
  2. DIC
  3. Vitamin K deficiency associated bleeding
  4. Simple volume replacement
  5. Routine prevention of IVH
questions.solution:
DIC & Vitamin K deficiency associated bleeding are valid indications for FFP transfusion in a neonate.

Valid indications for FFP transfusion in a neonate are:

  1. DIC
  2. Vitamin K deficiency associated bleeding
  3. Neonates with clinically significant bleeding
  4. Prior to invasive procedures with a risk of significant bleeding when there is an abnormal coagulation profile
  5. Afibrinogenemia
  6. Von-Willebrand factor deficiency
  7. Congenital antithrombin III deficiency
  8. Protein C and Protein S deficiency when specific factor replacement is not available.

FFP should not be used for

  1. Simple volume replacement/expansion
  2. Enhancement of wound healing
  3. Routine IVH prevention 
  4. Correction of coagulation profile abnormalities when there is no evidence of bleeding

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent chest infections. He passes frequent bulky greasy stools. He has also failed to gain weight despite a large appetite. On evaluation, the chloride concentration in his sweat is >60 mEq/L. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In this condition, hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis is seen.

Excessive loss of salt in the sweat predisposes young children to salt-depletion episodes. Therefore, these children present with hypochloremic alkalosis, resulting in increased serum bicarbonate levels. 

Cystic fibrosis or mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Clinical manifestations/ complications of cystic fibrosis include:
  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Gastrointestinal - 
    • Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes
    • Tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue - fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies
    • Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis
    • Distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults and meconium ileus in neonates
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

 The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach to management. The correction of the defect can be via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA-approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

questions.text: A mother is advised that the baby should be allowed to empty one breast completely before switching over to the other for optimum growth. All the following are reasons for this, except ____.

choices.text: Foremilk is rich in  sugar and vitamins

questions.solution:
While breastfeeding, the mother should allow complete emptying of one breast before switching over to the other. It is because the baby needs both fore-milk and hind-milk for optimum growth. Hind milk is rich in fats that provide more energy.

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

questions.text: The Ponderal Index in a baby with symmetrical IUGR is likely to be:
questions.solution:
A ponderal index of >2 is seen in symmetrical IUGR.

The Ponderal index can also be used to determine the degree of fetal malnutrition. It is calculated as the ratio of body weight in grams to length in cm expressed as PI = [weight {in gram} × 100] ÷ length {in cm}3. The normal value of the ponderal index is 2-2.5. Ponderal index > 2 is suggestive of symmetrical IUGR whereas value < 2 is suggestive of asymmetrical IUGR.

Small for gestational age implies birthweight is <10th percentile for gestational age. They are constitutionally small and nearly 70% of the babies falling under this category are not at any increased risk for adverse outcomes and will eventually attain normal growth patterns. The rest of the 30% are growth restricted and at increased risk of morbidity and mortality. Thus, SGA is not universally associated with growth restriction.

With respect to birth weight percentile, a newborn can be appropriate, small or large for gestational age.

Birth weight Terminology
<10th percentile Small for gestational age
>90th percentile Large for gestational age
Between the 10th and 90th percentile Appropriate for gestational age

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) refers to a fetal growth deficiency and an abnormal fetal growth trajectory. It is often classified as follows: 

Symmetric IUGR:

  • Insult on fetal growth occurs early.
  • As a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected.
  • It can be due to genetic causes, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections in the fetus.

Asymmetric IUGR

  • Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative brain-sparing effect.
  • The head circumference is relatively preserved compared to weight and length.
  • It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension(PIH), poor maternal nutrition, or maternal medical diseases.

Severe maternal hypertension causes symmetric IUGR, while late-onset maternal vascular disease (PIH, preeclampsia) causes asymmetric IUGR.

questions.text: A professor demonstrates the following reflex on a healthy child. He tests you by listing out the abnormal responses of this reflex and the conditions where those are seen. Which among them is wrongly paired?
questions.solution:
The reflex shown in the image is the Moro reflex. Kernicterus is associated with a loss of Moro reflex, not an exaggerated Moro reflex.

The above-animated gif shows a normal response to Moro's reflex where there are symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by anterior flexion of the upper extremities, associated with an audible cry.

 The Moro reflex:

  • It is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness.
  • The Moro reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age in normal infants. 
  • It can be elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backward onto the examiner’s hand.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: Feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly vera

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought to the emergency with symptoms of cyanosis, rapid breathing, and failure to thrive. The chest X-ray of the child is given below. Probable diagnosis is ____________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a snowman or figure of 8 appearance. The probable diagnosis in the above case is Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection.

TAPVC: Pulmonary veins instead of draining into left atrium drain into right atrium directly or indirectly. Following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior vena cava or the left innominate vein
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

questions.text: An unvaccinated child comes to OPD with complaints of 3 weeks of worsening cough. The paroxysms of cough end with a high-pitched inspiration and are precipitated by cold air and cold liquids. The organism causing the above disease can be cultured on which medium?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of pertussis/whooping cough caused by bordetella pertussis which can be cultured on the Bordet-Gengou medium.

Whooping cough derives its name from the inspiratory whoop at the end of a coughing bout. The disease courses over 3 phases after an incubation period of 2 weeks:

  • Catarrhal - lasts for 1-2 weeks and consists of cough, coryza, and nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • Paroxysmal - lasts for 2-6 weeks and consists of worsening paroxysms of productive whooping cough. It becomes more frequent and ends with vomiting. 
  • Convalescent - Intensity and frequency of cough decrease over 4 weeks.

The diagnosis is made on clinical grounds. A specific diagnosis can be done by isolation of the organism from a nasopharyngeal swab taken in the first two phases, and cultured on Bordet-Gengou medium.

Management involves antibiotic therapy and supportive care. The incidence of pertussis has decreased significantly after widespread vaccination. 

Other conditions with prolonged cough include adenoviral infections, reactive airway disease, foreign body in the airway.

Other options:

  • Potassium telluride agar - used for the culture of corynebacterium diphtheria.
  • Wilson Blair medium -used for the culture of salmonella.
  • Ghee broth - used for culture of yersinia

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after allegedly swallowing a coin while playing at home one hour ago. He appears to be in no apparent distress and is seated comfortably on the bed. Pulse rate is 100/min, respiratory rate is 19/minute and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. The chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The coin is lodged in the oesophagus. In this asymptomatic patient who has swallowed a blunt object, it is appropriate to observe the patient for 24 hours.

When foreign bodies are lodged in the oesophagus, the flat surface of the object is seen in the anteroposterior view and the edge is seen in the lateral view as shown in the radiological image above. The reverse is true for objects in the trachea.

Commonly, oesophagal foreign bodies lodge at the level of the upper oesophagal sphincter(Cricopharyngeus), the aortic arch or the lower oesophagal sphincter(Gastro-esophageal junction).

Management:

  • Asymptomatic blunt objects (coins) can be observed for 24 hours for their passage from the oesophagus to the stomach
  • Only if the child is symptomatic (drooling/breathing difficulty), immediate endoscopic removal is recommended
  • Sharp objects in the oesophagus, disc button batteries, or foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms mandate urgent endoscopic removal
  • Dislodging the coin using the Ryle’s tube carries the risk of perforation and is not advised

questions.text: A male baby was born by a cesarean section for obstructed labor. On examination of the baby, the anterior and posterior fontanels were wide open, the sutures were widely separated and the occiput was very prominent. MRI imaging showed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the dilation of the fourth ventricle with hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis. The diagnosis is likely to be Dandy-Walker syndrome. It is a congenital malformation that involves cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, hydrocephalus, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. It is associated with the atresia of the foramen of Magendie.

Other options

Option A- Mega cisterna magna can also cause hydrocephalus. It is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis.

Option B- Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, ataxia, breathing abnormalities including episodic apnea and hyperpnea. Imaging will show the presence of cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and molar tooth sign (a deepening of the interpeduncular fossa with thick and straight superior cerebellar peduncles)

Option C- Chiari malformation is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain. It consists of the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Often, there is also an associated developmental abnormality of the bones of the skull base leading to a small posterior fossa.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
questions.solution:
Ostium secundum ASD (labelled as 3) is the most common type of atrial septal defect (ASD), located at the mid-inter-atrial septum, in the region of the fossa ovalis.

ASD is characterized by an abnormal opening in the atrial septum allowing communication between the right and left atria. There are four types based on their location within the septum:

  • Secundum ASD - most common, usually an isolated abnormality
  • Primum ASD - associated with abnormal mitral valve leaflet (partial AV septal defect)
  • Sinus venous - is located at the junction of the superior vena cava and right atrium. Associated with anomalous right pulmonary venous return to the SVC or RA
  • Coronary sinus type ASD - also called unroofed coronary sinus

Ostium primum ASD: is located at lower atrial septum

Endocardial cushion defect/An AV septal defect/ AV canal defect consists of contiguous atrial and VSDs with markedly abnormal AV valves. The lesion is common in children with Down syndrome.

Congenital conditions associated with ASD include:

  • Down's syndrome - usually an ostium primum defect
  • Holt-Oram syndrome - autosomal dominant disorder with upper limb bony defects and cardiac septal defects, commonly secundum ASD
  • Ellis-van Creveld syndrome - chondroectodermal dysplasia associated with postaxial polydactyly and ASD
  • Lutembacher syndrome - combined ASD and mitral stenosis due to rheumatic valvulitis
  • Mitral valve prolapse

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What diagnosis would this signify in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the Mentzer index of less than 13, are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

The image below shows thalassemic facies (frontal bossing and maxillary hyperplasia) in a child with thalassemia major. 

Laboratory findings: Infants with severe β-thalassemia diseases experience increasing anemia following the newborn stage. The RBCs exhibit microcytosis, hypochromia, and target cells. Usually observed are nucleated RBCs, a distinct anisopoikilocytosis, and relative reticulocytopenia. Without transfusions, the Hb level frequently drops to 6 g/dL in a gradual manner.

MCV/RBC count also known as the Mentzer index can be used to distinguish thalassemia trait from iron-deficiency anemia. A Mentzer index of more than 13 is suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia while a value less than 13 points to the β-thalassemia trait. 

Prior to the initial blood transfusion, a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) sample must be provided to confirm the diagnosis of thalassemia, which is indicated by the absence of HbA and high levels of HbF.

Other options:

Option A: Glossitis, stomatitis, darkening of the skin on the knuckles and terminal phalanges, and enlargement of the liver and spleen are characteristics of megaloblastic anemia. Peripheral smear in megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils (shown below).

Option B: Iron-deficiency anemia has a Mentzer index of more than 13. Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia along with target cells.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia has a particular subtype called pernicious anemia. It is caused by insufficient vitamin B12 absorption through the gastrointestinal pathway, leading to vitamin B12 insufficiency. Macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are frequent observations in the peripheral smear associated with megaloblastic anemia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is an early symptom of the disease and typically occurs beyond 3 to 5 lobes.

questions.text: A newborn presented with microcephaly. On fundus examination, bilateral chorioretinitis is also found. Which of the following is the best investigation to confirm it as a congenital CMV infection?
questions.solution:
Urine examination is one of the best methods to diagnose congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

For diagnosis of congenital CMV infection, urine and saliva are the best specimens for culture and saliva and cord blood are the best specimens for polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Among the given options, the best option would be urine.

Congenital CMV infection:

Clinical features:

  • Characteristic signs and symptoms of clinically manifested infections: intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR), prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, blueberry- muffin-like rash, thrombocytopenia, purpura, microcephaly, and intracranial calcifications
  • Other neurological problems: Chorioreinitis, sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), and mild increases in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein.

Asymptomatic congenital CMV infection is possibly a leading cause of SNHL, which occurs in 7–10% of all infants with congenital CMV infection, whether symptomatic at birth or not.

Diagnosis:

  • Definitive diagnosis: By virus isolation or demonstration of CMV DNA by PCR (performed first 2 weeks of life).

  Treatment: Ganciclovir treatment can limit the hearing loss and improve the developmental outcome in symptomatically infected infants.

questions.text: While performing the following pediatric emergency procedure being performed on the model of an infant, which of the following indicates a wrong technique?

choices.text: Compression : Breath ratio should ideally be 30:2
Fingers should be lifted off the chest to allow effective recoil between compressions
Efficiency of chest compression should be assessed with brachial pulse periodically
Alternatively, the two thumb technique is equally effective

questions.solution:
The image shows infant CPR. Fingers should not be lifted off the chest between compressions.

The thumbs or the tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths in a minute.i.e 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if second rescuer arrives)

In infants, the brachial pulse should be assessed. (For children aged one to adolescence, the pulse should be checked at the carotid artery)

The two-finger technique and two thumb technique are considered to be equally effective.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about febrile seizures?

choices.text: They occur due to CNS infections
There may be history of prior afebrile seizures
Occur between the age of 6 to 60 months

questions.solution:
Febrile seizures are defined as seizures that

  • Occur between the age of 6 to 60 months
  • Associated with a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Do not occur as a result of central nervous system infections or any metabolic imbalance.
  • Occur in the absence of a history of prior afebrile seizures.

Depending on the duration and recurrence of the febrile seizure, they are classified as follows:

  • Simple febrile seizure: Generalised, usually tonic-clonic seizure, lasting for ≤15 minutes, and not recurrent within 24 hours.
  • Complex febrile seizures: Focal seizure, which is prolonged for >15 minutes and/or recurs in 24 hours.
  • Febrile status epilepticus: Febrile seizure lasting for >30 minutes.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with dyspnea on exertion and bluish discoloration of lips, which is relieved on squatting. A chest x-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Anterior deviation of the infundibular septum
Pulmonary venous connection to the SVC
Ostium secundum defect in the fossa ovalis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing cyanotic spells and chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette are suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition and has been classically characterized by the following components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks (hypoxic, “blue,” or “tet” spells) are a problem during the 1st year of life and may last from a few minutes to a few hours. The child can have shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips which is relieved on squatting. Short episodes are followed by generalized weakness and sleep. Severe spells may progress to unconsciousness and occasionally to convulsions or hemiparesis.

Older children with tetralogy of Fallot characteristically increase pulmonary blood flow by squatting. Squatting is a compensatory mechanism, it increases peripheral vascular resistance (PVR) and thus decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-ray describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot.
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

Other options:

Option B - A pulmonary venous connection to the superior vena cava (SVC) is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). It is a cyanotic congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins drain directly into the right atrium, coronary sinus, SVC, IVC, or ductus venosus.

On chest x-ray, supracardiac TAPVR presents with the snowman appearance of the heart which is as shown below

Option C - A downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve is seen in Ebstein anomaly, a cyanotic heart disease. Infants with severe disease present with marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly, and long holosystolic murmurs. Death may result from cardiac failure, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypoplasia. 

Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly caused by enlargement of the right atrium giving rise to a massive box-shaped cardiac shadow as shown below.

Option D - An ostium secondum defect in the fossa ovalis is the most common site of atrial septal defects (ASD). ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum causing a left-to-right shunt.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A widely fixed and split S2 is characteristic. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female is brought to the clinic for evaluation of primary amenorrhea. She complains of mild chest pain and cold extremities on exertion. Physical examination reveals a short-statured teenager, with a webbed neck and absence of secondary sexual characteristics. Blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg in bilateral upper extremities. There is a brachial-femoral delay. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: A continuous murmur in the interscapular region

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of coarctation of the aorta in a patient with Turner's syndrome who presents with primary amenorrhea. Patients with Turner's syndrome predominantly have elevated FSH levels and in some cases, the levels may be normal. But low FSH is not seen in these patients. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a condition where there is a narrowing of the descending aorta, which is located usually at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus just distal to the left subclavian artery. Children present with chest pain, cold extremities, and claudication with exertion. A physical examination will reveal hypertension in the upper extremities and a brachial-femoral delay. The blood pressure in the lower extremities may be unobtainable.

The first and second heart sounds are usually normal. P2 will be loud if there is associated pulmonary hypertension. Ejection systolic click and systolic ejection murmur may be heard in patients with a bicuspid aortic valve which is a common association. Systolic ejection murmurs and continuous murmurs may be heard in the interscapular regions. The diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography. A chest x-ray will show inferior rib-notching and a barium swallow will show a "reverse 3" appearance

 

Turner's syndrome (Hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism):

Primary amenorrhea refers to the failure of onset of menstruation, beyond the age of 16 years regardless of the development of secondary sexual characteristics. This patient's clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome. Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO).

In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The levels of Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) are indicative of the cause of hypogonadism. Increased levels of FSH and LH as seen in this patient are indicative of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is defined as 1) a decrease or absence in ovarian function and 2) due to absent negative sex-steroid feedback. 

The pathophysiology in Turner's syndrome is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism where there is oocyte atresia and the replacement of ovaries by fibrous streaks. This causes a decrease in serum estrogen levels which by negative feedback to cause a rise in Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and LH (gonadotropic hormones) as seen in this patient. Hypogonadism with a rise in gonadotropic hormones is known as hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 4-year-old fully immunized boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of dysphagia, fever, and drooling. On a lateral x-ray of the neck, a characteristic thumb sign was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a toxic-looking child with an x-ray of the neck showing thumb sign are suggestive of acute epiglottitis. 

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis. It is caused chiefly by Haemophilus influenzae type b.

Patients present with high fever, sore throat, dysphagia, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically assumes a tripod position, sitting upright and leaning forward with the chin up and mouth open.

The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (thumb sign).

The image given below shows the thumb sign seen in epiglottitis.

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to sudden and unpredictable airway obstruction. The treatment includes the following:

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Airway management - endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or, less often, by tracheostomy, regardless of the degree of apparent respiratory distress
  • Antibiotics - Parenteral ampicillin or third-generation cephalosporins
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema
  • Adequate hydration and humidified oxygen

Other options:

Option A: Croup or acute laryngotracheobronchitis is gradual in onset and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms. Also, fever is usually absent in such patients. X-ray of the chest shows typically a steeple sign due to narrowing of subglottic space.

The image given below shows the steeple sign seen in croup.

Option C: It is unlikely to be laryngeal diphtheria as it is mentioned that the child is fully immunized, and diphtheria is typically associated with membrane formation. 

The image given below shows membrane formation seen in diphtheria.

Option D: Retropharyngeal abscess is seen secondary to infections and usually does not present with fever. Children usually present with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, lateral to the midline. It is confirmed by a lateral X-ray of the neck which shows a widening of the prevertebral shadow.

The image given below shows x-ray findings seen in a retropharyngeal abscess.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant labourer who is HIV-positive delivers a healthy male baby. She was advised ART previously but has been non-compliant with her treatment. What is recommended by NACO with regards to feeding the baby?
questions.solution:
NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the infant feeding choice in the first 6 months. This is irrespective of the fact that the mother is on ART or the infant is provided with ARV prophylaxis for 6 weeks.

Breast-feeding and replacement feed simultaneously (mixed feeds) in the first 6 months should not be done, as it leads to mucosal abrasions in the gut of the baby, thereby facilitating HIV entry.

Breast-feeding should not be stopped abruptly. Only in situations where breastfeeding cannot be done (maternal death, severe maternal illness) or individual mother’s choice (at her own risk), then exclusive replacement feeding which is safe, sustainable, affordable and feasible can be started.

In resource-rich settings/developed countries, exclusive alternative formulations are recommended.

questions.text: An unimmunized child developed a fever, cough, and conjunctival congestion. 4 days later he developed a rash behind his ears which soon became widespread as shown in the image below. On examination, bluish-white spots were seen on the inner aspect of the cheek. Which of the following statements is false regarding the complications associated with this condition?

choices.text: Myocarditis is the most common cause of death
Hemorrhagic form of the disease is often fatal
Low levels of retinol is associated with increased  mortality
Acute otitis media is the most common complication

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing a morbilliform rash are suggestive of measles. The incorrect statement about the complication related to this condition is that myocarditis is the most common cause of death. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death in measles. 

Pneumonia in measles can be giant cell pneumonia which is caused by the virus directly or can be due to superadded bacterial infection.

Measles infection is caused by a single-stranded, lipid-enveloped RNA Paramyxovirus. It has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. These spots are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of the premolars.

A maculopapular rash appears 4 days after fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash. The morbilliform rash is shown below. 

The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. Sinusitis and mastoiditis are also seen. Black measles or hemorrhagic measles is a fatal complication characterized by hemorrhagic skin eruptions. It is rarely seen nowadays. Other complications include croup, tracheitis, bronchiolitis, diarrhea and vomiting, febrile seizures, and encephalitis. Myocarditis is a rare complication of measles.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is a rare but fatal complication characterized by cognitive decline, spasticity of limbs, and seizures. It is insidious in onset and clinical manifestations usually begin 7-10 years after primary measles infection. It is caused due to persistent infection with a genetically altered variant of the measles virus within the central nervous system.

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells. The image below shows a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell. 

Low serum retinol levels in children with measles are associated with higher morbidity and mortality and hence Vitamin A therapy is indicated for all patients with measles. The management is mainly supportive. There is no role for antivirals.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate is being evaluated for severe generalised edema. On examination, his blood pressure is within normal limits. Investigations revealed hypoalbuminemia and hemoglobin of 14 gm/dL. Urine analysis showed foamy urine and protein 4+. What is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a 1-day-old baby with generalized edema along with proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia points toward congenital nephrotic syndrome.

Nephrotic syndrome manifesting at birth or within 3 months of life is termed congenital nephrotic syndrome. It may be:

  • Primary - due to inherited disorders caused by mutations in NPHS 1, NPHS 2, WT1, or LAMB2.
  • Secondary - due to in-utero infections like cytomegalovirus infection, toxoplasmosis, syphilis, HIV infection, hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus HCV infection, infantile systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or mercury exposure.

Infants with congenital nephrotic syndrome most commonly present at birth with edema caused by massive proteinuria, and they are typically delivered with an enlarged placenta.

Severe hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and hypogammaglobulinemia occur due to the loss of filtering selectivity at the glomerular filtration barrier. 

The presence of elevated maternal and amniotic α-fetoprotein levels helps in prenatal diagnosis. A diagnosis of congenital nephrotic syndrome is made clinically in newborns or infants who demonstrate severe generalized edema, poor growth, and nutrition along with hypoalbuminemia, increased susceptibility to infections, hypothyroidism (from urinary loss of thyroxin-binding globulin), and increased risk of thrombotic events.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with nephritic syndrome classically present with tea- or cola-coloured urine due to hematuria, edema, hypertension, and oliguria. 

Option C: Neonatal haemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by a triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and impairment of renal function. It usually presents with severe anemia within a few hours after birth and progressively develops acute renal failure.

Option D: Hydrops fetalis can occur due to Rh incompatibility or other various non-immune causes ( infective causes include syphilis, parvovirus B19 infection, and intrauterine TORCH infections). These babies present with severe anemia.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, there was bluish discoloration of the lips and the mucosa. The respiratory rate was 65 cpm. On performing direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  What is the definitive management of this condition?

choices.text: Endotracheal intubation followed by delayed tracheostomy
Proton pump inhibitors to prevent reflux

questions.solution:
In the given scenario the baby presents with noisy breathing, respiratory distress(RR-65cpm) and bluish discoloration of the lips and mucosa(Cyanosis) and direct laryngoscopy showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of severe laryngomalacia. Supraglottoplasty is performed in a case of severe laryngomalacia.

In 15–20% of patients with laryngomalacia, symptoms are severe enough to cause progressive respiratory distress, cyanosis, failure to thrive, or cor pulmonale. In such cases, supraglottoplasty is performed.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly and the most common cause of stridor in infants and children. Stridor is exacerbated by any exertion: crying, agitation, or feeding. In the prone position, the stridor disappears.

Direct laryngoscopy shows elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds, and prominent arytenoids. 

In most children, only expectant observation is required as the condition resolves secondary to nervous system maturation, within 18 to 24 months of birth(Option A). However, neonates with severe laryngomalacia may develop marked upper airway obstruction resulting in cor pulmonale, life-threatening apneic episodes, feeding difficulties, obstructive sleep apnea, and failure to thrive. In such cases, surgical resection of supraglottic tissues and supraglottoplasty has been the favored approach.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with sickle-cell anemia was brought by his parents with complaints of fever and a runny nose. The child has a maculopapular rash with a lacy pattern on his trunk and extremities, sparing the palm and soles. He also has a rash on his face as shown below. What specific complication would you anticipate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical symptoms and the typical ‘slapped cheek appearance’ that is the erythematous facial flushing as shown in the image are suggestive of erythema infectiosum. A transient aplastic crisis is a complication that is anticipated in this patient. 

Erythema infectiosum or fifth disease is a viral infection caused by parvovirus B19. It usually has three phases:

  • First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks or slapped cheek appearance. Prodromal symptoms may occur
  • Second phase - begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk
  • Third phase - recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise

Parvovirus B-19-induced transient aplastic crisis is a complication seen in patients with all types of chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and pyruvate kinase deficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Coronary aneurysm is a complication of Kawasaki disease. Patients with this disease present with high fever for at least 5 days along with at least four out of the five characteristic features: polymorphous exanthem, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis with limbal sparing, lip cracking, and oral mucosal erythema with strawberry tongue appearance, cervical lymphadenopathy, and extremity involvement - erythema of palms and soles with edema of hands and legs.

The image given below shows strawberry tongue and erythema of hands seen in Kawasaki disease.

Option B: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a complication of measles. The characteristic presentation of measles includes a high fever, cough, coryza, and a maculopapular rash which typically begins after 3-5 days of fever in a cephalocaudal fashion involving the palms and soles. A pathognomonic feature of measles is the Koplik spots which are bluish-white spots located on the buccal mucosa opposite the 1st and 2nd molars.

The image given below shows rashes and Koplik spots of measles.

Option D: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis seen as a complication of group A streptococcal infection (more commonly seen with skin strains and a few pharyngeal strains). Common streptococcal infections in childhood are bacterial pharyngitis, Scarlett fever, non-bullous impetigo, and erysipelas. They present with acute pharyngitis or erythematous papulovesicular lesions which can become purulent.

The image given below shows the rash and strawberry tongue appearance of Scarlett fever.

questions.text: A neonate with vertebral and limb deformities was unable to pass meconium in the last 48 hours. Physical examination reveals abdominal distension with an anal dimple and Wangenstein's invertogram shows a low-lying defect.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is imperforate anus with VACTERL association (presence of vertebral and limb anomalies in addition to the anal atresia).

The neonate will present with an inability to pass meconium, abdominal distension, anal dimple, and sometimes passing meconium per urethra. It is divided into low intermediate and high lyings according to the Wingspread classification. Diagnosis is done using Wangenstein invertogram . Treatment is surgical.

Other options:

Option A: Hirschsprung disease is a congenital condition that occurs due to the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum. It is associated with Downs syndrome. Delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and severe chronic constipation are the features. Rectal examination shows a tight sphincter with an empty rectum. X-ray of the abdomen shows intestinal obstruction.

Option B: Meconium ileus is a condition, where thick meconium gets collected in the intestine and obstructs the lumen.  It is classically associated with cystic fibrosis. Features are intestinal obstruction, respiratory dysfunction, and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency with high salty sweat. X-ray shows calcified meconium pellets with air-fluid level (soap bubble appearance)

Option D:  Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus and occurs when a portion of the intestine twists around its blood supply. It shows features like abdominal pain, constipation, vomiting, and a tyre-like feel of the abdomen. The plain radiograph shows the pathognomic omega sign and coffee bean sign.

questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following findings are not consistent with this condition?

The clinical vignette of a child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding with low serum protein and albumin is suggestive of kwashiorkor, where simian facies is not seen. Simian facies is consistent with marasmus.

Kwashiorkor is a clinical syndrome seen in severe acute malnutrition (SAM). It is associated with pitting edema and apathy and affects children aged 1-4 years.

Edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs soon developing into generalized edema. Abdominal distension occurs with or without dilated bowel loops and hepatomegaly with fatty infiltrate.

Skin changes occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath forming patches of hyper and hypopigmentation called flaky paint dermatosis or crazy paving. The skin gets easily infected.

The image given below shows flaky paint dermatosis seen in kwashiorkor.

The hair is dull, brittle, sparse, and can easily be pulled out. It may lose its curl. Alternating bands of light and normal color hair may be seen, known as the flag sign. Children are miserable, apathetic, and often refuse to eat. There is marked muscle atrophy and growth retardation.

questions.text: A premature newborn infant is found to have a systolic murmur with late accentuation over the left infraclavicular area. This is due to the patency of ________
questions.solution:
A systolic murmur with late accentuation/ continuous murmur heard in premature infants is usually due to patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

In fetal life, the patency of ductus arteriosus is maintained by low oxygen tension and endogenously produced prostaglandins. In a full-term neonate, oxygen is the most important factor controlling the duct closure. In normal neonates, functionally ductal closure completes by 10-15 hours after birth. However, in premature infants, patent ductus arteriosus is common especially with the context of respiratory distress syndrome.

Note:

Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is more common in premature infants.

Other options:

  • VSD: Loud, harsh or blowing holo-systolic murmur present over the left sternal border, frequently accompanied by thrill.
  • PFO/ASD: Characteristic is the wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound. An ejection systolic murmur could be heard over the left sternal border.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy and congested pharynx. Two days later, he develops a maculopapular rash and changes in the tongue and hands as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features given is Kawasaki disease. The image shows strawberry tongue and erythema and edema of the hands. 

Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that predominantly affects coronary arteries. It is commonly seen in childhood. Symptoms include cervical lymphadenopathy, pharyngeal congestion, and maculopapular rash.

For the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease, the patient should have a fever for at least 5 days with any four of the following clinical features:

  • Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival injection
  • Erythema of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa 
  • Edema and erythema of the hands and feet
  • Rash
  • Nonsuppurative cervical lymphadenopathy

Early diagnosis of the disease is important to prevent coronary artery abnormalities.

Intravenous immunoglobulins are the mainstay of treatment. High-dose aspirin can also be given till the fever subsides. 

Other options

Option A- Erythema infectiosum is caused due to the infection of parvovirus B19. It presents with bright red erythema over the cheeks which gives it a slapped cheek appearance. The patients might also develop a maculopapular rash over the extremities.

Option B- Scarlet fever is caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus and presents with fever, exudative pharyngitis, and a bright red rash. The rash appears 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms. It starts on the neck and then extends to the trunk and extremities. The tongue is usually coated and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

Option C- Measles is caused by a paramyxovirus. It presents with fever, rash, exudative conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots. The rash begins on the face and neck and then spreads to the extremities.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. The mother says that she has been measuring his height and he has only increased in height by 4 cms over the last two years. On further investigations, a diagnosis of short stature is made. What is the expected growth velocity in this child?
questions.solution:
The growth velocity expected in an 8-year-old child is 6 cms/ year. The given scenario suggests that the child is suffering from pathological short stature, as he has grown only by 4 cms over the last two years. 

Height velocity is the rate of increase in height over a period of time. It is normal in physiological short stature. The average height velocity is 25 cms/ year in the first year and will be 75 cms tall at 1 year. At 2 years, the height is 90 cms and at 4 years, the child is 100 cm. After this, the child gains about 6cms every year until 12 years. If height velocity is lower than expected for age (as in this scenario), the child is likely to be suffering from a pathological cause of short stature.

Short stature

It is defined as the height below the third centile or less than two standard deviations (<-2SD) in a given population. Short stature may be physiological or pathological. Physiological short stature may be familial or constitutional.

Pathological short stature can be attributed to nutritional causes and systemic illnesses like congenital heat diseases, cystic fibrosis, asthma.

questions.text:
A 15-month-old child is admitted for the treatment of severe acute malnutrition (SAM). Identify the incorrect statements about the treatment of micronutrient deficiencies.
  1. Vitamin A should be supplemented on days 1, 2 and 14 
  2. Iron therapy can be started from day 2 onwards
  3. 5mg of folic acid to be given on day 1, 1mg to be given subsequently
  4. Copper and other trace minerals are added to the ReSoMal solution and given from day 1
  5. Zinc should be avoided till 2 weeks of stabilization is complete
questions.solution:
The incorrect statements are 2 and 5. Iron should not be given in the initial stabilization phase and zinc can be started in the stabilization phase, given with F75/F100 feeds or ReSoMal.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.

Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks (2nd to 6th week).

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14. (Dose: Age <6 months: 50,000 units; Age 6-12 months: 100,000 units; Age >12 months 200,000 units)
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
    • Give Vitamin K 2.5 mg as a single intramuscular dose at the time of admission.
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL.  After 3 days (usually within 1 week), transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with neurofibromatosis 1 (NF 1) brings her 9-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. She wants to know if the girl has NF 1. The presence of which of the following features would confirm NF 1 in the daughter?

choices.text: One iris hamartoma in the left eye

questions.solution:
The presence of one plexiform neurofibroma would confirm NF 1 in the daughter.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or von Recklinghausen's disease is an autosomal disease. NF1 is the most common of all neurofibromatosis. It is caused by a loss of function mutation, on the neurofibromin (NF1) gene. 

To diagnose neurofibromatosis 1, two or more of the following clinical manifestations should be present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules: > 5 mm in diameter in prepubertal and > 15 mm in diameter in postpubertal individuals
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris)
  • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

The FDA has recently approved a new drug selumetinib, mitogen-activated protein kinase 1 & 2 inhibitors for the treatment of NF1 in pediatric patients who are 2 years or older with symptomatic, inoperable plexiform neurofibromatosis. It can help reduce tumor progression.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a lack of object permanence?

choices.text: Uncovering a hidden toy after seeing that it was hidden
Banging two toys against each other
Staring momentarily at the spot where the toy disappeared from

questions.solution:
Staring momentarily at the spot where a toy disappeared from signifies a lack of object permanence or constancy (out of sight, out of mind). This is seen at 2 months of age and disappears at 8-9 months of age when the milestone of object permanence is attained.

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when it is not seen. When an object is hidden, a baby who is 4 to 7 months of age does not search for it and quickly gives up. However, a 9-month-old baby is able to understand that the hidden object continues to exist, will search for it, and be able to find it under a hidden cloth or behind the examiner's back. The child will enjoy the game Peek-a-boo at this stage of development.

 

The GIF below demonstrates object permanence. 

Other options:

Option A: Uncovering a toy (after seeing it hidden) is an example of object permanence, seen by 8 months of age.

Option B: Banging two toys against each other signifies an active comparison of objects, seen by 8 months of age.

Option D: Pointing to toys signifies interactive communication, seen by 10 months of age.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: A child developed dark coloured urine and flank pain 2 days after an upper respiratory tract infection. The physician suspects IgA nephropathy. What is the location of cellular injury in this condition?
questions.solution:
The location of cellular injury in IgA nephropathy (Berger nephropathy) is the deposition of IgA antibodies in the mesangial cell.

Mesangial cells are directly exposed to the circulation; therefore, they are affected in diseases characterized by the deposition of immune complexes.

Mesangial cell diseases:

  • IgA nephropathy
  • IgM nephropathy
  • Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Class II lupus nephritis
  • Diabetic nephropathy

Note: In IgA nephropathy gross hematuria often occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In contrast, a longer latency period of about 1-2 weeks is observed in acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

questions.text:
Ravi, an adolescent with sickle cell disease presents to the emergency room with chest pain and respiratory distress. Pulse oximeter shows 85% saturation in room air. Chest X-ray shows new radiodensities. Sputum and blood culture showed no growth. Which of the following are used in the management of this condition?
  1. Macrolide antibiotics
  2. Incentive spirometry
  3. Blood transfusion
  4. Third-generation cephalosporins
  5. Supplemental oxygen
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute chest syndrome and all of the above are used in the management. 

Acute chest syndrome (ACS) refers to a life-threatening pulmonary complication of sickle cell disease. It is diagnosed with the presence of a new radiodensity on chest radiography with any 2 of the following:

  1. Fever
  2. Respiratory distress
  3. Hypoxia
  4. Cough
  5. Chest pain

In this case, the child with sickle cell anemia satisfies the above criteria. He presented with chest pain and respiratory distress and his chest X-ray image shows new radiodensities. 

Most patients with ACS do not have a single identifiable cause. Infection is the most well-known etiology, yet only 30% of ACS episodes will have positive sputum or bronchoalveolar culture. The most common bacterial pathogens implicated are S. pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydia spp.

Oxygen should be supplemented to all patients who demonstrate hypoxia. 

Blood transfusion is the only method to abort a rapidly progressing episode of ACS.

Because of the clinical overlap between pneumonia and ACS, all episodes should be treated promptly with antimicrobial therapy, including at least a macrolide and possibly a third-generation cephalosporin.

Regular use of an incentive spirometer at 10-12 breaths every 2 hours can significantly reduce the frequency of subsequent acute chest pain episodes.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A slit-lamp examination of a patient showed the following picture. Which of the following is the molecular defect seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the Kayser–Fleischer ring, which is seen in Wilson's disease. ATP7B is the molecular defect seen in this patient. 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder. The abnormal gene for Wilson disease is present on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q14.3). It encodes ATP7B which is responsible for biliary copper excretion and for the incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin. In Wilson's, copper is not incorporated into ceruloplasmin, which decreases ceruloplasmin half-life and hence decreased ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL) are seen.

Clinical features of Wilson disease:

  • Hepatomegaly (with or without splenomegaly)
  • Acute/subacute/chronic hepatitis
  • Cirrhosis, ascites, portal hypertension
  • Tremor, dystonia, parkinsonism, behavioral, and psychiatric changes
  • Kayser-Fleischer ring
  • Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia (due to large amounts of copper released from damaged hepatocytes)
  • Renal Fanconi syndrome
  • Endocrinopathies

questions.text: What is the molar ratio of glucose to sodium in WHO low osmolality ORS and the rationale of this depends on which of the following transporter?
questions.solution:
The molar ratio of glucose to sodium in WHO low osmolality ORS is 1:1. The rationale behind this is based on the sodium and glucose cotransporter 1(SGLT-1).

In most cases of acute diarrhea, sodium, and chloride are actively secreted from the gut mucosa. However, the glucose-dependent sodium pump remains intact and functional transporting one molecule of glucose and dragging along a molecule of sodium and one water molecule across intestinal mucosa resulting in repletion of sodium and water losses. The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS).

The low-osmolality World Health Organization (WHO) oral rehydration solution (ORS) is now the global standard of care in the management of acute gastroenteritis. Oral rehydration is the preferred mode of rehydration and replacement of ongoing losses except for those with severe dehydration that might necessitate intravenous resuscitation. The osmolarity of low osmolarity ORS is 245mosm/L.
